guide.introduction: This is an easy-to-build simple solar engine, also known as a Trimmet. We will construct a direct-drive type (as opposed to a voltage-triggered) spinner that will really go nowhere fast in direct sunlight. Perfect for windowsills and desktops that get a lot of old Sol's rays. Many different styles are possible, but this is a straight-up basic spinner that never ceases to amuse.
guide.introduction_rendered:
This is an easy-to-build simple solar engine, also known as a Trimmet. We will construct a direct-drive type (as opposed to a voltage-triggered) spinner that will really go nowhere fast in direct sunlight. Perfect for windowsills and desktops that get a lot of old Sol's rays. Many different styles are possible, but this is a straight-up basic spinner that never ceases to amuse.

Relevant parts
  • Solar cell, amorphous, 1½" x 1½, the kind found in solar garden lights
  • Compact CD, 3" diameter
  • Small motor from an old CDROM or DVDROM drive
  • 1-Farad/5.5v capacitor
  • Nylon spacer, 7/16" OD x 1/4" ID x 7/16" L
  • 1½" x 1½" square cut of 1/2" thick nylon cutting board, acrylic, or block of wood. Use 2" dia. if circular cut
  • Wire, 26 AWG red, 4"long
  • Wire, 26 AWG black, 4"long
Tools
  • 1/16" drill bit
  • Dremel tool
  • Hot Glue gun & hot glue
  • Needle Nose Pliers
  • Soldering Iron and rosin core solder.
  • Wire cutter/stripper
  • bandsaw or hacksaw

parts.text: Solar cell, amorphous, 1½" x 1½, the kind found in solar garden lights
Small motor from an old CDROM or DVDROM drive
Nylon spacer, 7/16" OD x 1/4" ID x 7/16" L
1½" x 1½" square cut of 1/2" thick nylon cutting board, acrylic, or block of wood. Use 2" dia. if circular cut

lines.text: Begin by obtaining a small motor, such as the one pictured here from an old CD ROM drive.  They are usually soldered in place to a small board which is easily removable.  Unsolder the motor from the board and discard the board.
lines.text_raw: Begin by obtaining a small motor, such as the one pictured here from an old CD ROM drive.  They are usually soldered in place to a small board which is easily removable.  Unsolder the motor from the board and discard the board.

lines.text: Other CD ROMs may have the motor held in place with small screws at the base of the motor.  Remove the screws and then the motor.
lines.text_raw: Other CD ROMs may have the motor held in place with small screws at the base of the motor.  Remove the screws and then the motor.

lines.text: Here are the parts needed for the spinner:  compact CD, solar cell (removed from a garden pathway light), capacitor, spacer, motor, and base.
lines.text_raw: Here are the parts needed for the spinner:  compact CD, solar cell (removed from a garden pathway light), capacitor, spacer, motor, and base.

lines.text: If you ever want to up-size, use a standard size CD and additional solar cells wired in series.  But we're going to keep it simple here to get the basics down pat.
lines.text_raw: If you ever want to up-size, use a standard size CD and additional solar cells wired in series.  But we're going to keep it simple here to get the basics down pat.

lines.text: It is important to keep in mind that all parts during the assembly should be centered and balanced around the vertical axis, or the spinner will wobble wildly once it gets going.
lines.text_raw: It is important to keep in mind that all parts during the assembly should be centered and balanced around the vertical axis, or the spinner will wobble wildly once it gets going.

lines.text: Carefully center the solar cell over the CD and trace around the cell with a thin-tip marker.  Mark where the wires will pass through and drill two 1/16" holes.
lines.text_raw: Carefully center the solar cell over the CD and trace around the cell with a thin-tip marker.  Mark where the wires will pass through and drill two 1/16" holes.

lines.text: Insert the cell wires through the holes.  Apply a few globs of hot glue and gently press the solar cell down onto the CD, making sure it is centered in the box you traced.
lines.text_raw: Insert the cell wires through the holes.  Apply a few globs of hot glue and gently press the solar cell down onto the CD, making sure it is centered in the box you traced.

lines.text: Drill a 1/16" hole all the way through the nylon spacer from the side, about half way from one end.
lines.text_raw: Drill a 1/16" hole all the way through the nylon spacer from the side, about half way from one end.

lines.text: Scuff up the base of the motor around the center and also on the end of the nylon spacer.  This will give the glue good adhesion.
lines.text_raw: Scuff up the base of the motor around the center and also on the end of the nylon spacer.  This will give the glue good adhesion.

lines.text: Feed the red and black wires through the spacer from the side and up through the center.  Strip the ends and observing polarity, solder the red wire to the + (plus) terminal and the black wire to the - (minus) terminal of the capacitor.
lines.text_raw: Feed the red and black wires through the spacer from the side and up through the center.  Strip the ends and observing polarity, solder the red wire to the + (plus) terminal and the black wire to the - (minus) terminal of the capacitor.

lines.text: Pull the capacitor down to the spacer by pulling on the wires, then hot glue the spacer to the capacitor, taking care to make sure it is centered.
lines.text_raw: Pull the capacitor down to the spacer by pulling on the wires, then hot glue the spacer to the capacitor, taking care to make sure it is centered.

lines.text: The 1-farad capacitor will store the voltage generated by the solar cell while simultaneously powering the motor.
lines.text_raw: The 1-farad capacitor will store the voltage generated by the solar cell while simultaneously powering the motor.

lines.text: Trim the wires to about 1" in length and strip off 1/4" of insulation.  Tin the leads.
lines.text_raw: Trim the wires to about 1" in length and strip off 1/4" of insulation.  Tin the leads.

lines.text: Drill a 1/16" hole in the center of the cutting board base and push the motor spindle into the hole.  If it won't fit, use a next-larger size drill.  It must be a tight fit or the spinner won't spin!
lines.text_raw: Drill a 1/16" hole in the center of the cutting board base and push the motor spindle into the hole.  If it won't fit, use a next-larger size drill.  It must be a tight fit or the spinner won't spin!

lines.text: Now hot glue the other end of the spacer to the motor, making sure it is perfectly centered.  If it sets tilted or off center, carefully heat up the glue with a heat gun until it melts, and reposition the spacer.
lines.text_raw: Now hot glue the other end of the spacer to the motor, making sure it is perfectly centered.  If it sets tilted or off center, carefully heat up the glue with a heat gun until it melts, and reposition the spacer.

lines.text: Remove the base and place the motor assembly upside down on the CD.  Trim and strip the solar cell wires.  Twist and solder the red wire to red capacitor wire, and the black to black capacitor wire.  Then solder the wire bundles to the motor terminals.
lines.text_raw: Remove the base and place the motor assembly upside down on the CD.  Trim and strip the solar cell wires.  Twist and solder the red wire to red capacitor wire, and the black to black capacitor wire.  Then solder the wire bundles to the motor terminals.

lines.text: Now carefully center the motor assembly on the CD and hot-glue in place.  It may help to trace around the capacitor and use this as a guide before gluing.
lines.text_raw: Now carefully center the motor assembly on the CD and hot-glue in place.  It may help to trace around the capacitor and use this as a guide before gluing.

lines.text: Mount the motor spindle to the base.
lines.text_raw: Mount the motor spindle to the base.

lines.text: Place in a sunny spot and spin away!
lines.text_raw: Place in a sunny spot and spin away!

lines.text: If you've taken good care, the spinner will spin smoothly on its axis with minimum wobbling.  If not, it will hop all over the place once it gets going...but who says you can't put a 'spin' on spin?

guide.summary: Viva la BEAM-bots! Build dynamically entertaining spinners for your sunny spots and be mesmerized for minutes on end.
